vignette: Elain is a 63 year old mother of 5 children and 12 grandchildren, that presents to urgent care with a chief complaint of “I’m hallucinating.” Elain reports no history of depression or manic, and was in her usual state of health until 27 days ago when she witnessed a pedestrian be struck by a moving vehicle in her neighborhood. Elain tried to rescue the pedestrian, and even helped paramedics the responded to the scene provide chest compressions to the pedestrian. Unfortunately the pedestrian was pronounced dead on the scene. Since then, Elain has felt a sense of “dread” and “anxiety” everyday, and feels like every time she hears a cars wheels skid in the street, “I jump out of my skin.” The patient also reports that, when at work, she will have these persistent images of the pedestrian laying in the street, and “I just can’t get the images out of my head.” Elain reports that wakes two or three times a night with nightmares related to the event. Additionally, Elain herself has avoided drying, for fear she will be involved in a car accident herself. She was at work today and decided to come to urgent care because “I was hallucinating” and “I was at my desk and suddenly felt like my body separated from my mind, and I could see myself sitting at my desks, as if I was hovering from above.” Patient denied disorganized speech, thought insertion or thought broadcasting. She denied visual or auditory hallucinations.
diagnosis: Acute stress disorder (F43.0)
model_thoughts:
Okay, let me start by carefully reading the vignette. The patient is a 63-year-old woman named Elain who presents with a chief complaint of hallucinating. She witnessed a traumatic event 27 days ago where a pedestrian was hit and died despite her efforts to help. Since then, she's been experiencing dread, anxiety, hypervigilance (jumping at skidding car sounds), intrusive images of the event, nightmares, and avoidance of driving.

Wait, she mentions "hallucinating" but then denies actual visual or auditory hallucinations. Instead, she describes an out-of-body experience where she felt detached and saw herself from above. That sounds more like depersonalization or derealization. The timeline is clear—symptoms started right after the trauma, which is recent but lasting almost a month.

Considering the DSM-5-TR criteria, the key features here are exposure to a traumatic event (witnessing death), intrusive symptoms (images, nightmares), avoidance (driving), negative alterations in cognition/mood (persistent fear, horror), and arousal (hypervigilance, exaggerated startle). The duration is 27 days, which is more than a month for Acute Stress Disorder but less than for PTSD. Oh right, Acute Stress Disorder requires symptoms for 3 days to 1 month, so 27 days fits. PTSD would require symptoms for more than a month.

She also reports derealization (feeling detached, out-of-body experience), which is a dissociative symptom common in both ASD and PTSD. No history of mania or depression, so mood disorders might be less likely. The depersonalization could point to Depersonalization/Derealization Disorder, but that usually requires persistent symptoms without another disorder explaining it better. Here, it's clearly tied to the trauma.

Differential diagnoses should include trauma-related disorders first. Then maybe adjustment disorder if the symptoms were less severe, but here the trauma is extreme and symptoms match ASD closely. Anxiety disorders like Generalized Anxiety Disorder could be considered, but the direct link to trauma makes trauma disorders more likely. Also, she denies actual hallucinations, so psychotic disorders aren't fitting. The out-of-body experience isn't a hallucination but dissociation.

So primary diagnosis: Acute Stress Disorder, given the timeline and symptom cluster. Secondary could be PTSD provisional if symptoms persist, but currently it's within the acute phase. Other secondaries: Other Specified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder if there's any nuance, Adjustment Disorder with Anxiety, Depersonalization/Derealization Disorder, and maybe Unspecified Anxiety Disorder as a broader category. Gotta check the F-codes accordingly.
model_diagnosis:
1. Acute Stress Disorder - ICD-10 F43.0
2. Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (Provisional, given duration less than one month) - ICD-10 F43.10
3. Other Specified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder - ICD-10 F43.8
4. Adjustment Disorder With Anxiety - ICD-10 F43.22
5. Depersonalization/Derealization Disorder - ICD-10 F48.1

vignette: A 19 year old male comes to his primary care off reporting “I think someone has poisoned me at home.” The patient reports that about two and a half months ago, after he lost his job at a local arcade, he started noticing that he was feeling more sleepy at home. He states “I would go to bed around 7 p.m., right after dinner, and not wake up until about 12 p.m. the next day.” He reports before that time, he would go to bed around 10:30 p.m. and wake for work around 6 a.m. He states, “I started to notice that my mom would take longer preparing my plate of food for dinner, and I felt sleepy right after.” He endorsed associated low energy, low motivation and problems with concentration starting around that time. Patient goes on to say “over the past two months, every afternoon when I wake up, I can hear my parents whispering through the vents of the house, planning on killing me and replacing me with a different person.” Patient states he will sometimes also “hear them whispering when I’m at the store getting food and stuff, even though they are all the way back at home.” The patient reports that when he logs onto his ipad to play video games, “I can tell that some of the other characters of the game are my parents pretending to be other people. They are trying to get into my head.” The patient reports over the past 3 weeks he has stopped eating dinner, remains withdrawn to his room, and keeps the shades drawn “because I don’t want them looking into my windows.” The patient denied any other similar periods of symptoms like this in the past, denied illicit substance use (patients urine toxicology returns negative of all substance), and denied recent head injury or seizure. He denied active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. There are no guns in the home. About halfway through the exam, that patient grabs his jacket and runs out of the doctors office stating “forget it, I can tell you are working with my parents to kill me too.
diagnosis: Schizophreniform Disorder (F20.81) or F33.3 (Depression with psychotic features)
model_thoughts:
Okay, let me start by carefully reading the clinical vignette provided. The patient is a 19-year-old male who reports believing someone has poisoned him at home. He mentions symptoms starting about two and a half months ago after losing his job. He experiences increased sleepiness, low energy, low motivation, and concentration problems. He describes paranoid delusions, including hearing his parents whispering through vents about killing him and replacing him, even when they're not physically present. He also believes video game characters are his parents pretending to be other people. He has stopped eating dinner, withdrawn socially, and shows paranoid behaviors like keeping shades drawn. During the exam, he becomes suspicious and abruptly leaves.

First, I need to extract all relevant symptoms and organize them logically. Key symptoms include: paranoid delusions (poisoning, parents plotting to kill him), auditory hallucinations (hearing whispers), referential delusions (video game characters being his parents), social withdrawal, changes in sleep patterns (hypersomnia), low energy, anhedonia or low motivation, and concentration issues. The timeline is acute, starting after a stressor (job loss), with no prior similar episodes, no substance use, and no head injury.

Next, considering differential diagnoses. The prominent psychotic symptoms (delusions, hallucinations) suggest a primary psychotic disorder. Given the duration (over two months) and functional impairment, schizophrenia is a strong candidate. However, the onset is relatively recent, so schizophreniaform disorder is also possible. The presence of mood symptoms like low energy and motivation raises the possibility of a depressive episode with psychotic features, but the psychotic symptoms seem primary and mood symptoms secondary. Substance-induced psychosis is ruled out by negative toxicology. No medical causes mentioned, so delirium or psychotic disorder due to another medical condition is less likely. Brief psychotic disorder is possible but duration exceeds one month.

The patient's age (19) is typical for onset of schizophrenia. The paranoid type fits given the delusions and hallucinations. Schizoaffective disorder could be considered if mood symptoms were more prominent, but here they seem secondary. Delusional disorder might apply if hallucinations were absent, but auditory hallucinations are present, ruling it out. PTSD or acute stress disorder isn't indicated as no trauma is mentioned. Anxiety disorders don't align with the psychotic features.

Organizing the data: The core symptoms are psychotic (delusions, hallucinations), negative symptoms (withdrawal, avolition), and some mood-related issues (low energy). The absence of substance use or medical issues points toward a primary psychotic disorder. The acute onset after a stressor but persistence beyond that suggests schizophrenia rather than brief psychotic disorder.

Now, prioritizing diagnoses. Schizophrenia is the most likely given duration, symptoms, and impairment. Schizophreniaform disorder is secondary as it's similar but shorter duration. Major depressive disorder with psychotic features is possible but psychotic symptoms dominate. Delusional disorder is less likely due to hallucinations. Substance-induced psychosis is ruled out. Therefore, the primary diagnosis is schizophrenia, paranoid type. Secondary diagnoses include schizophreniaform disorder, major depressive disorder with psychotic features, delusional disorder, and brief psychotic disorder (though duration may exceed one month, so it's lower on the list).

Finally, ensure ICD-10 codes are accurate. Schizophrenia is F20.9, schizophreniaform disorder is F20.81, major depressive disorder with psychotic features is F32.3, delusional disorder is F22, and brief psychotic disorder is F23. The response should list these in order of likelihood without additional reasoning.

2. Schizophreniaform Disorder - ICD-10 F20.81
3. Major Depressive Disorder, Severe With Psychotic Features - ICD-10 F32.3
4. Delusional Disorder - ICD-10 F22
5. Brief Psychotic Disorder - ICD-10 F23

vignette: Stacy is a 54 year old Navy Veteran that comes to the emergency room complaining of “I feel like bugs are crawling all over me.” Patient reports this started about 36 hours ago after returning home from an elective surgical procedure (the patient had a ‘tummy tuck’). Following her surgeons orders, the patient has been on bed rest, abstaining from heavy activity. The patient reports “I also feel incredibly thirsty and I’m shaking like a leaf.” She denied any recent head trauma, and denied history of strokes or seizures. She lives alone in an apartment downtown. She I’ve lost a lot of friends over the years, so I mostly just stay home and delivery food if I’m hungry.” She reports “I have 4 or 5 beers a day”, stating she does not drink more than that “because I’ve been taking Klonopin for about 15 years and those two things do not mix.” The patient does admit, “my PCP stopped prescribing my Klonopin about a year ago, so I buy them from an online dispensary.” She acknowledges sometimes having a beer and Klonopin in the morning, “just to keep the shakes down.” On chart review, you see that the patient has also gone to several local emergency rooms over the past 2 years, with urine toxicology positive for alcohol, benzodiazepines, opiates and amphetamines, although in the controlled substance prescribing database, you see that the patient has never been prescribed opiates or amphetamines. Upon further questioning, that patient does acknowledges she has tried cutting back on alcohol use, since her family and friends has said “it seems like its taking over my life.” Unfortunately, she has not achieved any lengthy sobriety, and has actually found she is drinking more over the past year to achieve a similar effect. Blood labs on this visit indicate severely low sodium and potassium. Patient denied visual hallucinations, auditory hallucinations and denied sad or depressed mood.
diagnosis: Polysubstance use disorder, severe (F19.20); Alcohol use, with unspecified alcohol induced disorder (i.e. Beer Pantomania) (F10.99)
model_thoughts:
Okay, let me start by carefully reading the clinical case vignette about Stacy. She's a 54-year-old Navy Veteran coming to the ER with sensations of bugs crawling on her, which started 36 hours after an elective surgery. She's also experiencing thirst and shaking. She drinks 4-5 beers daily and has been using Klonopin for 15 years, but her PCP stopped prescribing it a year ago, so she buys it online. She sometimes combines beer and Klonopin in the morning to manage shakes.

Looking at her history, she's been to multiple ERs with urine tox positive for alcohol, benzodiazepines, opiates, and amphetamines, but she's never been prescribed the latter two. She admits to trying to cut back on alcohol because others have expressed concern, but she's drinking more to achieve the same effect. Labs show severely low sodium and potassium. She denies hallucinations or depressed mood.

First, I need to extract key symptoms and organize them logically. The main issues are tactile hallucinations (bugs crawling), shaking, thirst, polysubstance use, tolerance to alcohol, and electrolyte imbalances. The timeline is important—symptoms started post-surgery during bed rest, which might indicate withdrawal or another acute condition.

vignette: Collin is a 71 year old man, with remote history of alcohol use disorder, but has been sober for about 6 years. He used alcohol heavily from about 28 years of age to 65 years of age, acknowledging multiple inpatient medical hospitalizations for acute alcohol withdrawal as well as medical complications due to alcohol use, including acute liver failure and subsequent permanent gait abnormalities. He has come to his PCP with his wife reporting, “my family thinks I’m changing.” The wife interrupts the patient and states “you are changing, Collin.” The wife discloses that the patient wandered out of the house into the cold 3 times over the past month, and in the middle of the night. The wife states “I found him outside at about 2 a.m., it was 4 degrees outside and he was in his boxers, just standing there.” The patient himself recalls his wife bringing him inside, but can’t recall going outside. A recent CT scan in the local emergency room indicated no acute abnormalities or indication of stroke. The wife goes on to say, “Collin used to love cooking for the family, but now he can’t find his way around the kitchen”, stating the patient forgets to turn the burners off on the stove and even causes a fire in the kitchen a couple of months ago. The wife reports the family started noticing these changes about 2 years ago. There is no family history of dementia, Parkinson’s or Huntington’s disease. There are no known falls. Collin ultimately discloses “I do feel depressed these days”, reporting a worsening of sad and depressed mood starting about 2 years ago. He endorsed low motivation, anhedonia, and has even had passive suicidal thoughts over the past month. He denied any recent stressors, and denied returning to drinking alcohol or any drug use. Collin’s wife states, “he gets angry of the smallest things.” She goes on to say, “I have to help him get to the bathroom because he is incontinent in the bed very night now”, stating she also has to bath the patient because he can’t find his way around the bathroom. Finally, Collin’s wife states “he goes around making things up when we get around family, sometimes just inventing stuff on the whim, like saying he is making additions to the house or buying a new car, when that is both not true and has nothing to do with the conversation.
diagnosis: Alcohol induced Korsakov’s Syndrome (F10.26); Persistent depressive disorder (F34.1)

First, the user provides a detailed rubric for clinical reasoning, emphasizing data extraction and diagnostic reasoning. The assistant's response lists five diagnoses with ICD-10 codes. I need to reconstruct how the assistant arrived at each diagnosis based on the vignette.

Looking at the primary diagnosis: Major Neurocognitive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition (Alcohol-Induced Major Neurocognitive Disorder, Amnestic-Confabulatory Type). The vignette mentions a long history of alcohol use disorder, with complications like liver failure and gait abnormalities. The cognitive issues—wandering, memory loss, disorientation in familiar places, confabulation—align with alcohol-induced dementia. The absence of acute findings on CT and the timeline support this as a chronic condition.

Next, Major Depressive Disorder. Collin reports depressed mood, anhedonia, low motivation, and passive suicidal thoughts for two years. These meet criteria for MDD, and it's common in the context of neurocognitive disorders. 

Alcohol Use Disorder, in sustained remission, is mentioned due to his history, but he's been sober for six years. That's a key point for remission status.

Unspecified Neurocognitive Disorder is listed, possibly considering other etiologies despite alcohol being likely. Since the CT didn't show strokes, but vascular causes can't be ruled out entirely, it's a secondary consideration.

Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder seems off since it's for children/adolescents. Maybe the assistant considered Irritable Mood related to the neurocognitive disorder instead, but DMDD wouldn't fit an adult. Perhaps a better alternative would be Unspecified Depressive Disorder or adjustment issues, but given the criteria, MDD fits better.

The assistant probably prioritized conditions based on chronicity, symptom severity, and history. Alcohol-induced cognitive decline is prominent, depression comorbid, and other neurocognitive disorders to rule out. Confabulation and gait issues point towards Korsakoff or similar alcohol-related syndromes. The incontinence and disorientation suggest significant functional impairment, supporting a major neurocognitive disorder. 

They might have considered ruling out other dementias like Alzheimer's or vascular, but with no family history and negative CT, alcohol remains the leading cause. Depression could be independent or reactive to cognitive decline. The differentials need to account for all symptoms without overdiagnosing.

model_thoughts:
Okay, the user provided a clinical case vignette and asked for a structured list of the top 5 most likely DSM-5-TR psychiatric diagnoses with ICD-10 F-codes. I need to base this only on the information given, without adding any extra details.

First, let's extract key information from the vignette. Amber is 37, presents with suicidal ideation and frequent ER visits. She has a long history of self-harm (cutting since age 13), extensive trauma including sexual abuse and intimate partner violence. She reports constant flashbacks, nightmares, hypervigilance, and avoidance behaviors. The trigger for the current crisis is a breakup, leading to feelings of being "pissed off." She denies changes in appetite, energy, or anhedonia, and also denies mania, psychosis, or substance abuse. She mentions lacking family support.

Now, considering DSM-5-TR criteria, the primary diagnosis likely involves trauma and stressor-related disorders. The constant flashbacks, nightmares, hypervigilance, and avoidance strongly point to Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). The history of multiple traumas across different life stages supports this.

Next, the frequent suicidal ideation, self-harm behaviors, intense interpersonal conflicts, and fear of abandonment suggest Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD). The pattern of unstable relationships, identity issues (implied by being "too much to handle"), and recurrent suicidal behaviors align with BPD criteria.

The patient's chronic suicidal thoughts and self-harm might also indicate a persistent depressive disorder or other specified depressive disorder, given the ongoing distress without full criteria for major depression. She denies appetite or energy changes, so Major Depressive Disorder might not fit, but the chronicity suggests a depressive condition.

Adjustment Disorder with depressed mood could be considered due to the acute reaction to the breakup, but given the chronic trauma history, PTSD takes precedence. However, since the breakup triggered the current crisis, it's worth including as a secondary diagnosis.

Another consideration is Other Specified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder if there are mixed features, but PTSD seems well-supported. Also, Rule out Other Personality Disorders like Histrionic or Dependent, but BPD is most fitting.

Finally, ensuring the ICD-10 codes are accurate. PTSD is F43.10, BPD is F60.3, Other Specified Depressive Disorder is F32.8, Adjustment Disorder is F43.21, and Other Specified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder is F43.8. 

Need to list primary first, then four secondary diagnoses. Avoid non-psychiatric diagnoses. Check that all codes are within the F range. Double-check the vignette for any missed details, but it seems comprehensive. No need to include reasoning in the final output, just the list.
model_diagnosis:

2. Borderline Personality Disorder - ICD-10 F60.3
3. Other Specified Depressive Disorder - ICD-10 F32.8
4. Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood - ICD-10 F43.21
5. Other Specified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder - ICD-10 F43.8

vignette: Evan is a 62 year old white man, a Harvard Professor in Economics, with a multi-decade history of heavy alcohol use, but recently sober for approximately 7 months after completing substance rehabilitation in an outpatient settings. Evan presented to the emergency room after taking approximately ten 1 mg Klonopin in one setting, he states was “because I was tired and really wanted to go to sleep.” The patient indicates “I was not trying to kill myself” and “I regret taking that number of tablets at once.” He acknowledges recent discord with his wife, stating “I feel very afraid that she is going to leave me whenever we get into arguments, also indicating that after their most recent argument 2 days prior, he relapsed with alcohol use and drank about 6 standard drinks each of the last 2 days, and was intoxicated at the time of overdose. Patient reports “I used to be so active in teaching at Harvard. Now, I feel like I don’t have purpose”, stating that his department at Harvard has been assigning him less teaching or supervising obligations. The patient denied problems with active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. He denied recent or past symptoms of mania or psychosis. The patient acknowledged recent increased need for sleep, up to 14 hours a day, and still feeling tired when awake. He has had a approximately 10 pound unintentional weight loss over the past month. He acknowledges that there has been a significant increase in difficulty concentrating on texts he used to be able to attend to without issue. He states “sometimes it feels like I’m walking through mud throughout the day”, and “I want to get back to enjoying things in life again.” He acknowledges “sometimes I find myself just crying, but I have no idea why.” He denied feelings of hopelessness or despair. He denied trauma history, nor symptoms of OCD or panic. On arrival to the emergency room, patient acknowledged that he sustained a fall at home, which lead to his coming to the emergency room for evaluation. The patient is noted to have left peri-orbital ecchymosis and small, well-healing abrasions to his forehead. A head CT in the emergency room reveal a 2-3 mm subdural hematoma. The patient denied headache or vision changes in the emergency room. The emergency room clinician completed paperwork for the patient to be admitted on an involuntary basis to inpatient psychiatry. The following day, a repeat head CT revealed the subdural hematoma appeared 5-7 mm in length, yet the patient continued to deny vision changes, headache, confusion or extremity weakness. The patient reports he has been taking Cymbalta for a history of depression for over 5 years, and denied an untoward side effects.
diagnosis: Major depressive disorder, moderate, recurrent F33.1; Alcohol use disorder, severe
difficulty: Medium given patient minimizing extent of depression and that overdose was suicide attempt, although endorsing neurovegetative, cognitive, motivation, etc symptoms of depression.
model_thoughts:
Okay, let me start by carefully reading the clinical case vignette about Evan. He's a 62-year-old Harvard professor with a history of heavy alcohol use but has been sober for about 7 months after outpatient rehab. He presented to the ER after taking ten 1 mg Klonopin at once, saying he just wanted to sleep, not to kill himself. He regrets it and denies suicidal intent.

There's recent discord with his wife, fear of her leaving, and after an argument two days ago, he relapsed with alcohol, drinking about six drinks each day since. He was intoxicated during the overdose. He mentions feeling a lack of purpose because Harvard has reduced his teaching duties. He denies active suicidal or homicidal thoughts, mania, psychosis, trauma, OCD, or panic.

He reports increased sleep (up to 14 hours), still feeling tired, unintentional weight loss (10 pounds in a month), difficulty concentrating, anhedonia (wants to enjoy things again), and unexplained crying. However, he denies hopelessness or despair.

He had a fall at home, leading to the ER visit, with left peri-orbital ecchymosis and forehead abrasions. Initial CT showed a 2-3 mm subdural hematoma, and a follow-up CT showed it increased to 5-7 mm, but he denies headaches, vision changes, confusion, or weakness. He's been on Cymbalta for depression for over five years without side effects.

Now, I need to extract and organize the key information. Let me list the relevant details:

- Demographic: 62-year-old white male, professor.
- Substance use: History of heavy alcohol use, sober 7 months after rehab, recent relapse (6 drinks/day for 2 days), intoxicated at overdose.
- Overdose: Ten 1 mg Klonopin, stated intention to sleep, denies suicide attempt, regrets it.
- Psychosocial stressors: Marital discord, fear of wife leaving, reduced professional duties leading to lack of purpose.
- Mood symptoms: Increased sleep (hypersomnia), fatigue, unintentional weight loss, difficulty concentrating, anhedonia, unexplained crying. No hopelessness/despair.
- Exclusions: Denies suicidal/homicidal thoughts, mania, psychosis, trauma, OCD, panic.
- Medical: Fall at home, subdural hematoma (increasing size), no neurological symptoms.
- Treatment: On Cymbalta for depression >5 years.

Organizing this, the main issues are mood symptoms, substance use, overdose event, psychosocial stressors, and a medical condition (subdural hematoma). The mood symptoms (sleep increase, weight loss, concentration issues, anhedonia, crying) suggest a depressive episode, but he's already on an antidepressant. The substance use includes both alcohol and benzodiazepines (Klonopin). The overdose, though denied as suicidal, could be intentional or due to impulsivity from intoxication or distress.

Moving to diagnostic reasoning. Primary diagnosis: The mood symptoms align with Major Depressive Disorder (MDD). He has depressed mood (lack of purpose, crying), anhedonia, significant weight loss, hypersomnia, fatigue, concentration issues. However, he's on Cymbalta, which might indicate treatment-resistant or breakthrough depression. Given the recent stressors (marital, professional), this could be a recurrent episode. So, F33.1 (Major Depressive Disorder, recurrent, moderate) or F33.2 (severe) depending on symptom severity.

But wait, he denies hopelessness and despair, which are common in MDD, but the other symptoms are strong. Also, the overdose could be a suicide attempt despite his denial, which might indicate severity. However, he explicitly denies intent, so it's ambiguous.

Secondary diagnoses: Substance Use Disorders. He has a history of heavy alcohol use, recent relapse after 7 months sober. That suggests Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD), likely moderate to severe. Code F10.20 (Alcohol Use Disorder, moderate) or F10.21 (severe) depending on the history. Since he was in rehab, probably severe.

Also, Klonopin (clonazepam) is a benzodiazepine. Taking ten tablets at once, especially without prescription (not mentioned if prescribed), could indicate Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic Use Disorder. However, the vignette doesn't specify long-term misuse, just this overdose. But given his history with alcohol, polysubstance use is possible. So, consider F13.20 (Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic Use Disorder, uncomplicated) if there's a pattern, but the case only mentions this incident. Maybe it's not a use disorder, but rather intoxication or overdose. However, since he took a large amount, it could be misuse. But DSM-5 requires a pattern of use leading to impairment. Here, it's a single event, so maybe not a use disorder. Instead, consider F13.10 (Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic Intoxication) if he was intoxicated, but he took them to sleep, not necessarily for intoxication. Alternatively, it could be poisoning, but that's not an F-code.

Perhaps Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood due to the stressors (marital, professional). Code F43.21. Given the depressive symptoms, this might be a possibility, but the symptoms seem more severe and pervasive, leaning towards MDD.

Another consideration is Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia) if the depression is chronic, but he's on Cymbalta for over five years, which could be for MDD or dysthymia. However, the current symptoms might represent a major depressive episode on top of dysthymia (double depression), but not specified.

Also, the subdural hematoma could contribute to neurocognitive issues, but he has no neurological symptoms. However, it might be a medication side effect or related to the fall. But in psychiatry, we might consider Neurocognitive Disorder due to Traumatic Brain Injury (if the fall caused it), but he denies confusion or cognitive changes other than concentration issues from depression. So, probably not primary.

Additionally, the overdose could be classified as a Suicide Attempt or Self-Harm, but he denies intent. In DSM-5, Suicidal Behavior Disorder is a condition for further study, not an official diagnosis. So, if not suicidal, it might be Other Specified Self-Harm (F68.8) or related to substance use.

Given the complexity, let's list the top five likely diagnoses with ICD-10 codes.

Primary: Major Depressive Disorder, recurrent, moderate or severe. Since he's on medication and still symptomatic, possibly treatment-resistant. Code F33.2 (recurrent, severe without psychotic features) if the symptoms are severe, but he denies hopelessness, so maybe moderate. Let's go with F33.1 (recurrent, moderate).

Secondary: Alcohol Use Disorder, severe, in early remission but with recent relapse. The recent relapse after 7 months sober might indicate early remission, but since he drank recently, it's active. Code F10.20 (Alcohol Use Disorder, moderate) or F10.21 (severe). Given multi-decade heavy use and rehab, likely severe. So, F10.21.

Third: Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic Use Disorder, unspecified. He misused Klonopin, which could indicate a use disorder, but we don't have a pattern. However, taking a large amount impulsively might suggest misuse. Since it's a single event, maybe not, but given his substance history, it's plausible. Code F13.20 (uncomplicated) or F13.10 (intoxication). But for a use disorder, we need more criteria. Perhaps it's Other Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic-Related Disorder, but that's not standard. Alternatively, Poisoning by benzodiazepines, but not an F-code. So, I'll include F13.20 as a possibility.

Fourth: Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood. Given the stressors (marital discord, reduced professional duties), and the depressive symptoms, this could be primary. But the symptoms seem to meet MDD criteria, so Adjustment Disorder is less likely if MDD is present. However, if the depressive episode is directly related to stressors, it might be Adjustment Disorder. But the severity and symptoms suggest MDD. So, maybe as a secondary diagnosis. Code F43.21.

Fifth: Other Specified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder, if the overdose is related to stress but not quite Adjustment Disorder. Or maybe Unspecified Depressive Disorder if not meeting full criteria. But he seems to meet MDD criteria.

Also, consider Benzodiazepine Intoxication at the time of overdose. Code F13.129 (Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic Intoxication, unspecified). Since he was intoxicated when he took the overdose, and he drank alcohol, so possible polysubstance intoxication.

But the instructions say top five diagnoses with F-codes, so I need to choose the most likely.

Let's prioritize:

1. Major Depressive Disorder, recurrent, severe without psychotic features (F33.2) – given the symptom severity (weight loss, hypersomnia, concentration issues, anhedonia, crying), and functional impairment.

2. Alcohol Use Disorder, severe (F10.21) – history of heavy use, rehab, recent relapse.

3. Sedative, Hypnotic, or Anxiolytic Use Disorder, moderate (F13.20) – misuse of Klonopin, though pattern not detailed, but given alcohol use disorder, likely comorbid.

4. Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood (F43.21) – as a reaction to stressors, but since MDD is present, this might be secondary or comorbid.

5. Other Specified Depressive Disorder (F32.89) – if the depressive symptoms don't fully meet MDD criteria, but they seem to. Alternatively, since he's on Cymbalta, it could be Treatment-Resistant Depression, but that's not a separate code. Or perhaps Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition (subdural hematoma), but no clear link. Code F06.31 might apply if the depression is due to the hematoma, but he had depression before, so likely primary.

vignette: Melanie is an 11 year old girl who was brought to urgent care by her mother after being sent home from school for “using racial slurs.” Melanie is the product of a full-term, uncomplicated pregnancy, vaginally delivered with normal APGAR (Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, Respiration) score at birth. Melanie used her first word “Momma” around 48 months of age, and didn’t start noticing other children playing with her until about 6 years old. Even at 6 years old, Melanie would not respond to her name when called, often appearing like she was in a daydream, and would often do a lot of “rocking” or “spinning” when anxious. Melanie’s mother indicates “Melanie is a unique kid. She doesn’t really make good eye contact with me, her father or her friends, and seems to be overly focused on doing puzzles all day. She has a hard time making friends, because all she wants to do is work on puzzles, and does little interactive play with others.” Melanies mother also indicates “if we take her puzzle away from her for dinner, she will have a complete ‘meltdown’ and be inconsolable for a good hour, ultimately leading to us having to give her the puzzle back.” Around 8 years of age, Melanie was found blinking her eyes repeatedly, and would say “I have to do it” whenever family questioned the eye blinking. The eye blinking slowly went away, but seemed to be replace by Melanie contorting her neck repeatedly, and especially when getting ready for school or leaving the house. Now, Melanie slaps herself in the head repeatedly when stressed, to the point that family has to adorn Melanie with soft gloves so she does not cause injury. About 13 months ago, Melanie start screaming out racial slurs when in the grocery store and school, and this would last for about 5 minutes in duration, until she was able to calm down. Otherwise, Melanie denied problems with sad, depressed or hopeless mood, nor problems with auditory or visual hallucinations. Melanies mother denied observations of bizarre rituals such as excessive handwashing, counting or organizing, but does report Melanie has a strong and persistent interest in puzzles. Melanie denied active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others.
diagnosis: Autistic Disorder (F 84.0); Tourette Syndrome (F95.2)
difficulty: Medium given LLM would need to be able to know that Tourette syndrome (vs Tic disorder) can only be diagnosed with both motor AND vocal tics present for at least 12 month duration, which the patient has here.

He denied that the experiences are particularly distressing, and states “I just want to make sure I’m ok.” The patient denied recent or past disorganized speech, disorganized thought process or feelings of paranoia or persecution. vignette: Collin is a 13 year old boy that was brought to his pediatrician by his mother for “all he does is talk back and kick me.” Collin appears calm and in good behavioral control in the exam room, but his mother indicates “he was such a good boy until about a week ago when he seemed to be look more sad, not playing his video games like he usually does, and keeping himself in his room.” Collin himself acknowledges “I just have not felt myself; I usually like to go outside and play with friends, but I just don’t feel like I have the energy to do that anymore.” He states his appetite is much less over the past week, but denied any known unintentional weight loss. He acknowledges “I would never kill myself, but I have thought about how the world might be better without me in it.” He denied prior self harm or suicide attempt. Mom reports that about 2 weeks ago the patient’s father lost his job unexpectedly, and the family is now going to have to move to a new state to find new work. The patient reports feeling much more tired during the day now, even after getting about 10 hours of sleep each night. He has had problems concentrating in school, and has failed multiple exams at school over the past week. He denied problems with recent or past mania, psychosis, trauma, substance use or anxiety. Mom states “if he is not sad and crying, he is angry and kicking me”, acknowledging patient has engaged in some light property destruction at home and bullying his younger siblings.
diagnosis: Adjustment disorder with disturbance in conduct (F43.24) +/- Adjustment disorder with depressed mood (F43.21)
difficulty: Medium. LLM may ‘over diagnosis’ depression instead of adjustment disorder based on duration of symptoms.
model_thoughts:
Okay, let me start by carefully reading the clinical vignette. Collin is 13, brought by his mother because he's talking back and kicking her. He seems calm in the exam room, but his mother says his behavior changed about a week ago—he became sad, stopped playing video games, and stayed in his room. Collin himself mentions not feeling like himself, lacking energy to play with friends, reduced appetite, and thoughts about the world being better without him. He denies suicide plans or self-harm.

The timeline is important here. The mother notes that two weeks ago, the father lost his job, and the family might have to move. Collin feels tired despite sleeping 10 hours a night, has trouble concentrating, and failed multiple exams recently. He denies mania, psychosis, trauma, substance use, or anxiety. The mother adds that when he's not sad, he's angry, engaging in property destruction and bullying siblings.

Hmm, the core symptoms point to depressive features: sad mood, anhedonia (not playing games), fatigue, concentration issues, and thoughts of worthlessness. The irritability and aggression are notable, especially in adolescents, where depression can manifest as irritability rather than just sadness. The onset seems acute, tied to the stressor of the father's job loss and potential move.

But wait, the mother mentions "if he is not sad and crying, he is angry and kicking me." That's a key detail—alternating between sadness and anger. The property destruction and bullying siblings suggest behavioral issues. Could this be a disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD)? He's 13, and DMDD requires severe recurrent temper outbursts and persistent irritability between outbursts. The vignette mentions anger and kicking, but it's not clear if the irritability is persistent between episodes. Also, DMDD symptoms must be present for at least 12 months, and here it's only about a week or two.

Maybe it's a major depressive episode with mixed features? He has depressive symptoms but also irritability and aggression. However, the vignette denies mania, so bipolar might not fit. Adjustment disorder with mixed disturbance of emotions and conduct is a strong possibility given the clear stressor (father's job loss, moving) and the mix of depressive symptoms and behavioral issues.

Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) could be considered due to the talking back, anger, and defiance, but ODD usually has a longer pattern, not just a week or two. The acute onset following a stressor leans more toward adjustment disorder.

Intermittent explosive disorder is another thought because of the aggression, but that requires recurrent outbursts, and the timeline here is too short.

Anxiety is denied, so rule that out. No trauma history, so PTSD isn't likely. Substance use is denied too.

Putting it all together, the primary issue seems to be an adjustment disorder with mixed emotional and behavioral symptoms, given the acute stressor and the combination of depression and conduct problems. Major depressive disorder is a close second because of the clear depressive symptoms, but the acute stressor and behavioral components make adjustment disorder more fitting as the primary. DMDD is less likely due to the short duration. ODD and IED are possible but not as aligned with the acute stress response.
model_diagnosis:
1. Adjustment Disorder with Mixed Disturbance of Emotions and Conduct - ICD-10 F43.25
2. Major Depressive Disorder, Single Episode, Mild - ICD-10 F32.0
3. Oppositional Defiant Disorder - ICD-10 F91.3
4. Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder - ICD-10 F34.8
5. Intermittent Explosive Disorder - ICD-10 F63.81

vignette: Patient is a 59-year-old female with an unassessed complex trauma history presenting with not-just-right sensations related to hair and bumps growing on her face that cause substantial distress, despite acknowledging that the hairs and bumps are not always physically present. To manage this distress, she keeps tweezers on her person at all times, checks mirrors every 30 minutes when at home, and avoids staying home for extended periods. She also exhibits contamination concerns manifesting as excessive handwashing (25+ times daily) and using barriers to avoid direct contact with "unclean" surfaces out of fear of contracting an illness. Patient believes that she must act on her physical sensations or contamination-related thoughts most of the time or the distress will persist. Patient also collects items like My Little Ponies and Trolls. She has filled her home, garage, basement, a rented warehouse, and now pays to store items in a neighbor's garage despite saying she has little to no money to pay for these expenses. She expresses strong attachment to these possessions, stating she would "NEVER" sell them, and has a history of repurchasing items she previously attempted to sell. Patient's medical history is significant for AIDS (diagnosed 2003, currently on Odefsey), and past surgical interventions following a car accident. Her psychological history includes previous diagnoses of PTSD and Bipolar Disorder (which she disputes). Current symptoms of a major depressive episode include anhedonia, restlessness, sleep disturbance (averaging 4 hours nightly), feelings of worthlessness, and difficulty concentrating. These episodes emerge roughly every few month. The patient denied symptoms of psychosis as well as symptoms related to higher than usual energy or goal-directed activity at any time in the past. She endorsed suicidal ideation without current plan or intent, rating likelihood of attempt at 1%. Social support is reportedly limited, with the patient living alone with her two dogs, having infrequent contact with her daughter, and minimal social connections beyond casual acquaintances while shopping. She denied distress or functional impairment resulting from any traumatic events.
diagnosis: Obsessive-compulsive disorder with poor insight (F42.2); hoarding disorder with excessive acquisition (F42.3); major depressive disorder (moderate, recurrent) (F33.1)

There's also contamination concerns with excessive handwashing and avoidance behaviors. These point towards obsessive-compulsive symptoms.

She collects items extensively, filling multiple spaces, and has strong attachment to them despite financial strain. This suggests hoarding behavior. The depression symptoms like anhedonia, sleep issues, worthlessness, and concentration problems indicate a major depressive episode. The mention of past PTSD and bipolar disorder, but she disputes bipolar and denies manic symptoms, so I need to consider if bipolar is still relevant. However, the vignette says episodes emerge every few months, which might point to recurrent depression rather than bipolar.

Also, the patient has a trauma history but denies distress or impairment from it, so PTSD might not be current. The medical history includes AIDS, which is important but not a psychiatric diagnosis, so I won't include it.

Now, prioritizing the diagnoses: the OCD symptoms are prominent, so that could be primary. Hoarding is separate but significant. Major depressive disorder is recurrent based on the episodes. I should rule out bipolar since she denies manic symptoms. Trauma-related disorders might be considered but she denies impairment, so it's lower priority.

Let me list them in order of likelihood based on the symptoms described. OCD first, then hoarding disorder, major depressive disorder, persistent depressive disorder if the depression is chronic, and maybe unspecified trauma-related disorder if applicable. But since she denies distress from trauma, perhaps adjustment disorder isn't fitting. Alternatively, other specified obsessive-compulsive and related disorder could cover the not-just-right sensations if they don't fully meet OCD criteria.

Wait, the contamination concerns and checking behaviors align with OCD. The hoarding is separate but often comorbid. Depression is clearly present. I need to check if the depression is part of bipolar, but she disputes bipolar and no manic symptoms, so recurrent depressive disorder makes sense. For trauma, maybe other specified trauma disorder if history is complex but no current PTSD symptoms.

Finally, ensuring the F-codes are correct for each diagnosis. OCD is F42, hoarding F42.3, major depressive disorder recurrent F33.9, persistent depressive disorder F34.1, and other specified trauma disorder F43.8. vignette: The patient is a 25-year-old male who presented with delayed responses and was vaping during intake. He currently works full-time managing his hot tub repair company and lives with his girlfriend. His medical history includes multiple substance addictions, particularly opioids (requiring Suboxone and later Methadone treatment), and previous diagnoses of OCD, ADHD, anxiety disorder, and depressive disorder. He reports a significant history of head trauma (8 concussions), one seizure episode while incarcerated, and multiple incarcerations for offenses including gun possession, burglary, and vehicle theft. His psychiatric medication history includes Adderall, Concerta, Zoloft, an unspecified antidepressant, and Trazodone. The chief complaint involves symptoms that began at approximately age 18 during his first incarceration and have intensified in the past year, coinciding with work stress. Problematic behaviors include arranging items in specific places with extreme rigidity (unable to buy new items that don't have a "place"), performing rituals in sets of three, and a specific handwashing ritual. He experiences intrusive thoughts about harming others (particularly fears of stabbing, shooting, or raping strangers) and engages in compulsive behaviors (brushing his hand from hairline to ear three times) to alleviate associated anxiety. He also reports persistent checking behaviors due to memory doubts, a need for things to feel "just right", and specific ordering rituals. Additionally, he endorses current anhedonia, decreased appetite, fatigue, and concentration difficulties that wax and wane every few months. He shared that these symptoms are distressing, though mildly impairing in his social, work, and leisurely activities. He denies current suicidality, self-harm, or hallucinations/delusions. He reports a childhood history of conduct problems (skipping school, lying, stealing, fighting) and adult behaviors including illegal activities, irresponsibility, deceitfulness (e.g., using fake identifications) and reported guiltlessness after harming others or damaging property. His childhood conduct problems (e.g., fighting) have resulting in the concussions reported in the medical history, and his illegal activities have resulted in two incarcerations. When asked about one such activity (stealing a car), he reported no remorse, instead blaming the victim for calling the police. The assessment revealed that these behaviors have continued for years in multiple settings, though as of late, he reported that he has not engaged in any illegal activities because he does not want to return to jail for a third time.
diagnosis: Obsessive-compulsive disorder, fair insight (F42.2); Recurrent Major Depressive Disorder (mild) (F33.0); antisocial personality disorder (F60.2)

vignette: Patient is a 25-year-old transgender male currently living with parents who are reportedly non-supportive, and he works as a hospital lab technician. He presents with severe symptoms characterized primarily by intrusive thoughts related to morality, contamination, and harm. Unwanted thoughts include fears of transmitting sexual fluids to others (which he believes would make him "a rapist"), concerns about accidentally killing insects, moral distress about consuming animal products, and beliefs that viewing violent media constitutes "condoning" violence. To manage these thoughts, he engages in extensive reassurance seeking, repeatedly checking lab results at work, avoiding video games and television, dietary restrictions, and some handwashing. He reports these symptoms significantly interfere with daily functioning, preventing him from living independently. They cause intense distress that frequently culminates in panic attacks. Patient has a complex history related to his gender identity, reporting he has identified as male throughout his life despite being assigned female at birth. He is currently taking low-dose testosterone but conceals this from his family, who he believes are interfering with his plans for gender-affirming surgeries. He reported childhood "delusions" about being "from a fantasy world and chosen by gods" that resolved by age 18. Patient previously took fluvoxamine for panic symptoms until approximately age 24, reporting significant symptom exacerbation upon discontinuation. He describes himself as introverted with limited social connections, identifying as asexual, though questioning if this might be avoidance related to triggering thoughts. His social anxiety dates back to middle and high school, when he was "pretty much mute" with few friends. Patient describes his mood as "always a little depressed" with recent intensification. He endorses feeling sad, empty, and hopeless most days, anhedonia, sleep disturbances, psychomotor retardation, fatigue, worthlessness, guilt, concentration difficulties, and suicidal ideation. He frequently believes he "needs to be dead" and that suicide would be "the moral thing to do" following morally repugnant intrusive thoughts, though he denies current plan or intent (estimating a 5% chance of suicide within three months). He struggles with activities of daily living without parental support and expresses frustration that his thoughts and behaviors interfere with his gender expression. Despite these significant symptoms, he demonstrates good insight, noting that his thoughts are not consistent with who he is and what he values.
diagnosis: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder with good insight (F42.2); Gender Dysphoria in Adults, posttransition (F64.0); Major Depressive Disorder, Single Episode, Moderate (F32.1)

vignette: Patient is a 47-year-old female residing in the Northeastern United States who recently lost her job due to alleged "disorganization", which she contests as the actual reason for termination. Currently unemployed but financially stable for the near term, she is pursuing employment opportunities abroad with plans to relocate to Vietnam in September 2021. The patient lives alone with no local support system and has recently withdrawn from her social connections following concurrent stressors of job loss and the death of her pet cat, expressing irritation with friends' "bad advice". She denies substance use, maintains good physical health aside from requiring iron supplementation, and reports a childhood head injury at age 11 without loss of consciousness. Patient describes longstanding organizational tendencies dating back to approximately age 8, recalling precise block stacking and meticulous desk organization throughout her schooling. These behaviors were particularly pronounced during her high school years when her family sponsored relatives' citizenship, resulting in 16 people residing in her home. She demonstrates consistent contamination-related behaviors, including using barriers when touching public surfaces, frequent hand sanitization (predating the pandemic), and immediate cleaning of any perceived contamination. The patient engages in regular cleaning throughout the day, reporting an inability to tolerate "a single dirty dish in the sink" and an immediate need to address any uncleanliness she observes. Notably, she denies these behaviors cause distress or any impairment, stating she "enjoys" cleaning and maintaining organization. Patient reported persistent depressed mood, anhedonia, restlessness, fatigue, and feelings of worthlessness over the past two weeks, but said that these symptoms are manageable. She denies current or past suicidal ideation. While she denies feeling "up", "high", or "hyper", she describes persistent irritability manifesting as social withdrawal and increased argumentativeness, characterizing herself as "more lucid" than others because she doesn't "follow the script". She denies symptoms consistent with mania or hypomania, including grandiosity, decreased need for sleep, pressured speech, racing thoughts, distractibility, or increased goal-directed activity. The patient acknowledges experiencing an unspecified "extremely traumatic event" but denies re-experiencing it in distressing ways. Assessment ruled out panic disorder, social anxiety disorder, substance use disorders, psychotic disorders, eating disorders, and generalized anxiety disorder.
diagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder, recurrent, mild (F33)

vignette: Patient is a 24-year-old gender fluid individual with a BA in creative writing and sociology who is currently living with their parents while taking courses part-time and seeking employment. They describe their living situation as "overwhelming" due to parental boundary issues, though they maintain a supportive romantic relationship since 2019. Their psychiatric history includes diagnoses of MDD and GAD at age 15-16, PTSD in 2016 following emotional abuse by high school friends, and ADHD in 2018 (without neuropsychological evaluation). Current medications include Lisdexamfetamine 50mg (since 2018), various supplements, and a contraceptive injection. They previously tried multiple antidepressants (2011-2015) but discontinued each after approximately two weeks due to suicidal ideation and, in one case, motor disturbances. The patient consumes alcohol socially (3-5 drinks monthly) and has been vaping marijuana 1-3 times weekly for three months primarily to aid sleep and manage anxiety. The patient's primary symptoms onset around age 5 with intrusive visualizations of falling down stairs along with perfectionism through rewriting notes until they felt "just right". Currently, they experience significant distress when surroundings are not in the "right spot", spending up to 12 hours reorganizing belongings without breaks, which would cause severe distress if interrupted. This "not just right" feeling impairs their ability to meet deadlines, complete job applications, and fulfill social obligations. They also engage in checking behaviors when packing (counting socks repeatedly, checking for essential items) and experience distressing sexual intrusive thoughts. Additionally, the patient exhibits skin-picking behaviors, spending over an hour picking at ingrown hairs until bleeding, scratching their neck and jaw during conversations, and tearing at cuticles, with symptoms worsening during periods of anxiety. They've attempted to stop by wearing pants constantly but have been unsuccessful. The patient has a significant history of depression with three past suicide attempts (overdoses in 2014, 2015, and 2017) and self-injury through cutting (stopped in 2017). They currently experience passive suicidal ideation, anhedonia, decreased appetite, sleep difficulties, psychomotor agitation, feelings of worthlessness, and concentration problems, though they report 0% chance of self-harm in the next three months. Social anxiety manifests as persistent fear of judgment and rejection, with distressing rumination about social interactions and excessive reassurance-seeking that has cost them friendships. The patient also reported past sexual abuse by a boyfriend for 4-5 months but denied PTSD symptoms. They disclosed a history of binge eating episodes. During the binge, they ate more rapidly than normal and felt disgusted and embarrassed after. After these eating binges, pt fasted for ~3 days. These eating binges occurred <1 time per week, and the patient has not engaged in these behaviors in the past 2 months.
diagnosis: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (F42.2); Major Depressive Disorder (moderate, recurrent) (F33.1); Social Anxiety Disorder (F40.10); Excoriation Disorder (F42.4); Other Specified Eating Disorder: bulimia nervosa (of low frequency and limited duration) (F50.89)
model_thoughts:
First, I need to analyze the clinical case vignette and extract all relevant information to form a structured list of diagnoses. The response must only include the top 5 most likely DSM-5-TR psychiatric diagnoses with ICD-10 F-codes, without any clinical reasoning. I should base this only on the information provided.

Let me extract and organize the key symptoms and history from the vignette:

**Patient Demographics and Background:**
- 24-year-old gender fluid individual.
- Living with parents, part-time student, seeking employment.
- Supportive romantic relationship since 2019.

**Psychiatric History:**
- MDD (Major Depressive Disorder) and GAD (Generalized Anxiety Disorder) diagnosed at age 15-16.
- PTSD diagnosed in 2016 following emotional abuse.
- ADHD diagnosed in 2018 without neuropsychological evaluation.

**Current Medications:**
- Lisdexamfetamine 50mg (since 2018) for ADHD.
- Various supplements.
- Contraceptive injection.

**Past Medications:**
- Multiple antidepressants (2011-2015) discontinued due to suicidal ideation and motor disturbances.

**Substance Use:**
- Alcohol: socially, 3-5 drinks monthly.
- Marijuana: vaping 1-3 times weekly for three months for sleep and anxiety.

**Primary Symptoms:**
- Onset around age 5 with intrusive visualizations of falling down stairs and perfectionism (rewriting notes until "just right").
- Current distress when surroundings are not in the "right spot", spending up to 12 hours reorganizing belongings without breaks, severe distress if interrupted.
- "Not just right" feeling impairs deadlines, job applications, social obligations.
- Checking behaviors: counting socks repeatedly, checking for essential items when packing.
- Distressing sexual intrusive thoughts.
- Skin-picking behaviors: over an hour picking at ingrown hairs until bleeding, scratching neck and jaw during conversations, tearing cuticles. Worsens with anxiety. Attempts to stop unsuccessful.

**History of Depression:**
- Three past suicide attempts (overdoses in 2014, 2015, 2017).
- Self-injury through cutting (stopped in 2017).
- Current symptoms: passive suicidal ideation, anhedonia, decreased appetite, sleep difficulties, psychomotor agitation, feelings of worthlessness, concentration problems.
- Reports 0% chance of self-harm in next three months.

**Social Anxiety:**
- Persistent fear of judgment and rejection.
- Distressing rumination about social interactions.
- Excessive reassurance-seeking that has cost friendships.

**Trauma History:**
- Past sexual abuse by a boyfriend for 4-5 months, but denied PTSD symptoms (though PTSD was diagnosed in 2016 from emotional abuse).

**Eating Behaviors:**
- History of binge eating episodes: ate more rapidly than normal, felt disgusted and embarrassed after.
- After binges, fasted for about 3 days.
- Occurred less than once per week, but not engaged in past 2 months.

Now, I need to identify DSM-5-TR diagnoses based on these symptoms. I should consider the primary diagnosis and four secondary diagnoses, all psychiatric with ICD-10 F-codes.

**Step 1: Identify the most prominent disorder.**

The patient has symptoms that strongly suggest Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD):
- Intrusive thoughts (visualizations, sexual intrusive thoughts).
- Compulsions: perfectionism (rewriting notes), need for things to be in the "right spot" (reorganizing for up to 12 hours), checking behaviors.
- These cause significant distress and impairment in social and occupational functioning.
- Onset from age 5, which is early but possible for OCD.

Also, skin-picking is mentioned, which could be Excoriation (Skin-Picking) Disorder, but it might be part of OCD or a separate condition. In DSM-5, Excoriation Disorder is separate from OCD.

**Step 2: Consider depressive symptoms.**

The patient has a history of MDD and current depressive symptoms: passive suicidal ideation, anhedonia, decreased appetite, sleep issues, psychomotor agitation, worthlessness, concentration problems. There are past suicide attempts. This could indicate a current Major Depressive Episode, possibly recurrent.

**Step 3: Social anxiety symptoms.**

Persistent fear of judgment, rumination, reassurance-seeking – this aligns with Social Anxiety Disorder (Social Phobia).

**Step 4: ADHD diagnosis.**

ADHD was diagnosed in 2018 and is being treated with Lisdexamfetamine. The vignette doesn't specify current ADHD symptoms, but since it's a chronic condition and medication is ongoing, it should be considered.

**Step 5: Trauma and PTSD.**

PTSD was diagnosed in 2016 from emotional abuse, and there's history of sexual abuse, but the patient denies PTSD symptoms now. However, the diagnosis might still be relevant if symptoms are present or in remission. But for current diagnosis, if symptoms are denied, it might not be active. The vignette says "denied PTSD symptoms" in the context of sexual abuse, but PTSD was previously diagnosed from emotional abuse. I need to see if current PTSD is indicated. The patient has intrusive thoughts, but those are more OCD-related. Avoidance, hyperarousal aren't explicitly mentioned. So, PTSD might not be the primary focus.

**Step 6: Eating behaviors.**

Binge eating episodes with fasting afterwards – this could indicate Bulimia Nervosa or Binge-Eating Disorder. However, the episodes occurred less than once per week and haven't happened in the past 2 months. For Bulimia Nervosa, binge eating and compensatory behaviors (like fasting) need to occur at least once a week for three months. Here, it's less frequent and not recent, so it might not meet full criteria. But it could be specified as in partial remission or other specified feeding or eating disorder.

**Step 7: Perfectionism and "not just right" feelings.**

These are classic for OCD, but also could be related to Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder (OCPD). However, OCPD is a personality disorder, and the symptoms here seem more ego-dystonic and cause distress, which is more typical of OCD rather than OCPD.

**Step 8: Skin-picking.**

vignette: The patient is an 18-year-old non-binary college freshman with a complex psychiatric presentation. They report a history of childhood anxiety, perfectionism, and ritualistic self-punishment behaviors starting in the third grade. Currently, their most debilitating symptom is anxiety about "contaminated air" when others cough or sneeze, prompting them to cover their face and hold their breath even when the trigger is far away or on television. They engage in checking and counting behaviors based on the number 3, including checking mirrors while driving, locking/unlocking their car, and tapping their toothbrush. These compulsions are experienced as uncontrollable, with the patient reporting they sometimes modify behaviors (like holding an imaginary door handle in their pocket) when the original compulsion would be disruptive. At approximately age 16, the patient developed anorexia nervosa, restricting their food intake and ultimately requiring intervention from parents and a treatment team. Despite gaining weight under external pressure, the patient continues to restrict eating, has a distinct fear of gaining weight, becoming fat, fasting until dinner, drinking coffee to intentionally upset their stomach. Their BMI currently falls within the normal range. Around the same time their eating disorder developed, the patient experienced depressive symptoms including hopelessness, low motivation, and self-harm behaviors (pulling hair, cutting, punching stomach). They had suicidal ideation during high school, including thoughts of jumping in front of a train and fantasizing about wandering into hallways during a school shooting. Current suicidal thoughts are less frequent and persistent. Current depressive symptoms have been subsyndromal (though not entirely absent) for about 7 months. Specifically, the patient currently denies experiencing depressive symptoms for more than a few hours every couple of weeks but rates their chance of self-harm in the next three months at 50% (suicide attempt chance at 0%). They report minimal alcohol and marijuana use. Notably, the patient expresses resistance to treatment, stating that "getting better means getting fat" and feeling they need to "stay sad for a while longer".
diagnosis: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (F42.2); Anorexia nervosa, restricting type, in partial remission (F50.014); Major depressive disorder, recurrent, in partial remission (F33.41)

The mention of ritualistic self-punishment since childhood might indicate obsessive-compulsive personality traits. Given the patient's age and symptom onset, adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depressed mood should be considered due to the transition to college. 

The primary diagnosis should be obsessive-compulsive disorder given the ego-dystonic nature of the compulsions and anxiety-driven obsessions. Anorexia nervosa remains active despite weight restoration. The depressive symptoms, while currently less severe, have historical significance. The personality traits and adjustment issues round out the differential. 

I'll list them in order of clinical priority based on current impairment and diagnostic criteria.

vignette: The patient is a 22-year-old female from the Southeastern United States with a history of Depression (2019), Anxiety (2019), and OCD (March 2021). She recently transitioned from working as a childcare specialist to self-employment as a freelancer. Her medical history includes anemia and IBS, for which she takes daily iron supplements. The patient previously attempted treatment with Zoloft (10mg) for OCD symptoms but discontinued due to emotional blunting effects. She reports consuming alcohol 1-2 glasses a few times monthly and using marijuana daily when available, which she finds helpful for intrusive thoughts despite occasionally triggering anxiety. The patient's most distressing symptoms involve intrusive thoughts about sexually harming children, accompanied by physiological responses that she describes as "groinal". These thoughts were particularly distressing during her work as a childcare specialist, where she engaged in compulsive staring at children's genital areas to "prove" she wasn't sexually attracted to them and sometimes avoided changing diapers due to fear of sexual arousal. After experiencing an intrusive dream about sexually harming her brother in January 2021, she experienced physical symptoms (shaking, freezing) when interacting with him and subsequently increased their time together as a form of reassurance. Additionally, the patient reports significant health anxiety focused on getting cancer, HIV, and STIs, leading to excessive symptom research. The patient experiences panic attacks (1-2 times monthly) lasting 15-30 minutes when triggered by intrusive thoughts, with symptoms including shortness of breath, crying, sweating, racing heart, chest pain, and feelings of detachment. She reports seeking reassurance from her mother when these thoughts become overwhelming. The patient also endorses distressing and functionally impairing social anxiety in small groups, leading to significant avoidance; however, she stated that this anxiety is primary due to her unwanted/intrusive thoughts rather than a fear of being judged. She reports experiencing over 50 depressive episodes in the past year, each lasting at least two weeks with symptoms including decreased appetite, sleep disturbance, fatigue, guilt, concentration difficulties, and thoughts of death. She described these episodes as challenging to manage, but "not completely debilitating".
diagnosis: OCD, mild, fair insight, with panic (F42.2); Illness Anxiety Disorder (F45.21); Major Depressive Episode, recurrent, moderate (F33.1)

vignette: Erik is a 10-year-old male who recently completed 4th grade in a gifted math program. He lives with his biological parents and seven-year-old brother, with whom he has "constant" conflict including arguing, screaming, and hitting. Erik has a developmental history of severe temper tantrums prior to age 4, with behavioral challenges emerging in kindergarten and worsening in subsequent grades. His mother reports that her son engages in "constant defiance", experiences rapid mood changes, and demonstrates impulsive behavior, including occasional incidents of pulling knives (though never pointing them at anyone). Daily arguments at home frequently escalate to physical aggression, particularly with his mother and brother. Erik has expressed statements such as "I wish I could go to sleep and never wake up" and reports feeling depressed "randomly" a couple times per month since second or third grade, though he denies daily depressive symptoms or changes in sleep or appetite. Erik's behavioral difficulties have manifested in both home and school environments. In school, he has engaged in speaking out of turn, refusing to follow directions, agitating teachers, and having "screaming matches" with staff. Despite these challenges, Erik maintains high grades across subjects (with math being his most difficult class at a B), has several friends, and is described as a leader in social interactions. He has a Section 504 plan that allows for movement opportunities and frequent breaks when needed. In March 2019, Erik began taking 2mg of Guanfacine (extended release) for attention/concentration deficits, which has helped reduce impulsivity and improve behavioral control, though aggressive and defiant behaviors have continued. His mother reports implementing a point system for rewards and consequences but notes limited effectiveness due to inconsistent expectations between parents. Formal assessment indicates that Erik demonstrates a pattern of emotional dysregulation, defiance, and aggressive behavior, with physical aggression occurring approximately every other day at home. Assessment also confirms prior symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, which are present across settings and contribute to emotional dysregulation and academic underperformance relative to ability.
diagnosis: Oppositional Defiant Disorder, Moderate (F91.3); Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder, Combined Type (F90.2)

Next, the assessment notes inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity across settings, which improved with guanfacine. That strongly suggests ADHD, Combined Presentation. Oppositional Defiant Disorder is also evident given the defiant, argumentative behavior and conflict with authority figures.

The depressive symptoms are sporadic, so unspecified depressive disorder fits better than persistent depressive disorder.
